bib.title: Surrogate Ratio Methodology For The Indirectdetermination Of Neutron Capture Cross Sections.

free_txt: M.Guttormsen,H.T.Nyhus
B.L.Goldblum,S.G.Prussin
L.A.Bernstein,W.Younes
M.Guttormsen,H.T.Nyhus
Main reference.
CACTUS array at the Oslo Cyclotron
Laboratory.
M.M.
SD: ERR-ANALYS was updated in Subent 002.
CP were detected with eight particle
telescopes, each  consisting of a front Si dE
detector and a back Si(Li) E detector with
thicknesses of 140 and 3000 microm, respectively,
placed at an angle of 45  degrees relative to the
beam direction.Intrinsic particle energy resolution was
determined using Am-241 source to be 50 keV at
Ealpha=5.486MeV.
Average energy resolution of the particle detectors
200 keV over entire particle energy region.
Array of 28 NaI gamma-ray detectors, which
intercepted a solid angle of 15% of 4PI, surrounded
the target and particle detectors. FWHM of the detector
output varied from 80 keV at alpha-ray energy of
1.33 MeV up to 250 keV at alpha-ray energy of 8 MeV.
CACTUS array at the Oslo Cyclotron
Laboratory.
45-MeV He-3 ion beam. Beam currents 2 nA.
Particle-gamma coincidence.
SRM- surrogate reaction method.
Ion beam details.
Details of response function of CACTUS array.
Details of extraction of particle-gamma coincidence
spectra.
Dy-161,162,163 targets were self-supporting and
isotopically  enriched to approximately 95% in the
isotope of interest with thicknesses of
approximately 2 mg/cm**2. An 11-day experiment
on the Dy-164 target was carried out with 38-MeV He-3
ions at the Oslo Cyclotron Lab. The Dy-164 target,
enriched to approximately 98.5% in isotope of interest,
was prepared as a self-supporting foil of approximately
1.7 mg/cm**2 thickness.
Request for the data was sent 24.09.2010.
Data were received form B.Golblum 28.09.2010.

0.free_text: Cross section extracted using the surrogate reaction method (SRM) with similar compound nuclei pairs relative to the evaluated cross section obtained from ENDF/B-VII.0 as a function of neutron energy obtained via the (He3,He3') inelastic reaction with a g-ray energy threshold of 500 keV and 2 MeV.

free_txt: The ratio of the number of particle-gamma
coincident events to produce two different compound
nuclei (in this case, Dy-162 and Dy-164) using the
same surrogate reaction,(He3,He3'),was determined.
Ratio was normalized at EA=7100 keV. To obtain the
Dy-161(n,gamma) cross section, the normalized ratio
data were multiplied by ENDF/B-VII.0 Dy-163(n,gamma)
cross section matched at excitation energy.Result was
then shifted into equivalent neutron energy by
subtracting the neutron separation Dy-162 compound
nucleus (Sn=8196.9 keV) from excitation energy.
For CACTUS detector response function about 6 %.
Statistical and systematical errors
included:
* Uncertainty of unfolding of CACTUS detector response
function.
* Uncertainty in energy identified as normalization
point for gamma-decay probability.
* Uncertainty in contributions to particle-gamma
spectra due to target contaminants.
Uncertainty of monitor reaction c-s as
conservative estimate.
Data were received from author B.Golblum
Data are given on Fig.1 of J,PR/C,81,054606,2010.
Data obtained by threshold of 2 MeV (Fig.1b)

0.free_text: Cross section extracted using the surrogate reaction method (SRM) with similar compound nuclei pairs relative to the evaluated cross section obtained from ENDF/B-VII.0 as a function of neutron energy obtained via the (He3,He3') inelastic reaction with a g-ray energy threshold of 500 keV and 2MeV.

free_txt: The ratio of the number of particle-gamma
coincident events to produce two different compound
nuclei (in this case, 162Dy and 164Dy) using the
same surrogate reaction,(He3,He3'),was determined.
Ratio was normalized at EA=7100 keV. To obtain the
Dy-161(n,gamma) cross section, the normalized ratio
data were multiplied by ENDF/B-VII.0 Dy-163(n,gamma)
cross section matched at excitation energy.Result was
then shifted into equivalent neutron energy by
subtracting the neutron separation Dy-162 compound
nucleus (Sn=8196.9 keV) citation energy.
Normalization parameter A was defined to be
0.95+-0.01 and 1.05+-0.01 (stat.uncertainty)
at EA=7010 keV for Eth= 500 keV and 2 MeV,respectively.
Statistical and systematical errors
included.
Data were received from author B.Golblum
Data are given on Fig.2 (open circles) of

0.free_text: Cross section extracted using the surrogate reaction method (SRM) with similar compound nuclei pairs relative to the evaluated cross section obtained from ENDF/B-VII.0 as a function of neutron energy obtained via the (He3,He4) pickup reaction with a g-ray energy threshold of 500 keV and 2MeV.

free_txt: The ratio of the number of particle-gamma
coincident events to produce two different compound
nuclei (in this case, 162Dy and 164Dy) using the
same surrogate reaction,(He3,He3'),was determined.
Ratio was normalized at EA=7100 keV. To obtain the
Dy-161(n,gamma) cross section, the normalized ratio
data were multiplied by ENDF/B-VII.0 Dy-163(n,gamma)
cross section matched at excitation energy.Result was
then shifted into equivalent neutron energy by
subtracting the neutron separation Dy-162 compound
nucleus (Sn=8196.9 keV) citation energy.
Normalization parameter A was defined to be
1.06+-0.01 and 1.21+-0.01 (stat.uncertainty)
at EA=5700 keV for Eth= 500 keV and 2 MeV,respectively.
Digitizing error of EN.
Digitizing error of DATA
Statistical and systematical errors
included.
Data obtained by threshold of 500 keV (Fig.2a).
Data obtained by threshold of 2 MeV (Fig.2b).
